Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Singapore
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Jeffrey Wayne Streicher of The University of Texas at Arlington to conduct a research project, entitled "Genetic consequences of forest fragmentation in two frog species from Singapore," during the summer of 2012 at National University of Singapore in Singapore. The host scientist is Dr. David Bickford.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is that it provides a valuable commentary on the effects of deforestation in a tropical region with high levels of biodiversity. Using populations of frog species from the heavily urbanized country of Singapore, rates and patterns of gene flow are being characterized among several discontinuous forest fragments.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This funding supported a research project investigating gene flow among populations of a frog species, the Four-lined Tree Frog (Polypedates leucomystax), in the highly urbanized country of Singapore. In Singapore I was hosted by Dr. David Bickford of the National University of Singapore.

During my time in Singapore we collected a total of 94 Four-lined Tree Frog samples from 10 natural areas on the island: Labrador Park, Kent Ridge Park, Mount Faber, Telok Blangah Hill Park, Bukit Timah Nature Reserve, Bukit Batok Nature Park, Holland Woods, MacRitchie Nature Reserve, Lornie Forest, and Bukit Batok Town Park. We isolated DNA from these samples in the laboratory. Using mitochondrial DNA, we identified that the Four-lined Tree Frogs we collected in Singapore are closely related to populations from Malaysia. In addition, we examined the feasibility of using molecular tools developed for population genetics studies of other Asian tree frogs (i.e., microsatellites) on the Four-lined Tree Frog.

We also experimented with using skin-swabbing (with a sterile cotton swab) as a method for obtaining DNA from endangered frog species. We successfully isolated DNA and sequenced several mitochondrial and nuclear genes from skin cells swabbed off of a rare Cinnamon Tree Frog (Nyctixalus pictus) from Bukit Timah Nature Reserve.

My participation in the EAPSI program allowed me to form many professional relationships (with individuals at the National University of Singapore, Singapore Zoo, and the National Parks Board) and mentor undergraduate students at the National University of Singapore. The geographic sampling and preliminary laboratory results obtained during my Singapore trip have positioned our research group to characterize fine-scale gene flow in an amphibian species that inhabits a predominantly urban landscape. Specifically, this will allow us to determine how some amphibian species persist despite a backdrop of urban encroachment.
